{{Coord|31|20|02|N|34|48|08|E|display=title}} [[File:Araqeeb Demolished615.JPG|thumb|250px|Demolished house in Al-Araqeeb]] '''Al-Araqeeb''' ({{Lang-ar|قرية العراقيب}} ''Qarya al-‘Arāqīb'',<ref>also Arakiv, Arakib, Arakeeb, Araqib, Kafr al-Arakib</ref> {{lang-he|אל-עראקיב}}) is an [[unrecognized village]] of the Al-Turi [[Arab people|Arab]] [[Bedouin]] tribe, five miles (8 km) north of [[Beersheba]] demolished and rebuilt over 100 times.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/israel-destroys-bedouin-village-119th-time-171003135958243.html|title=Israel destroys Bedouin village for the 119th time|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-10-04}}</ref><ref name="Levy Levac" >[[Gideon Levy]] and Alex Levac [http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/twilight-zone/1.550550 'Drafting the blueprint for Palestinian refugees' right of return,' at [[Haaretz]] 4 October 2013]</ref><ref name="Cook">[[Jonathan Cook]], [http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/comment/treatment-of-palestinians-is-apartheid-by-any-other-name 'Treatment of Palestinians is apartheid by any other name,'] [[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] July 10, 2013 p.2</ref><ref>[https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/20251-israel-demolishes-arab-village-in-negev-for-87th-times 'Israel demolishes Arab village in Negev for 87th time,' at Memo Middle East Register 6 August 2015]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.palinfo.com/site/pages/details.aspx?itemid=79367|title=Israel demolishes Bedouin village al-Araqib for 100th time - Palestinian Information Center|access-date=2016-07-01}}</ref>
==History== The At-Turi cemetery of the Al-Araqeeb Bedouin dates back to 1914. After the 1948 Arab–Israeli War, Israel began to displace the Bedouin of the Negev desert, and by 1953 had expelled 90% of the roughly 100,000 people in the northern Negev. According to [[Eyal Weizman]], various methods, from strafing to massacres and tent burning were employed, and the refugees moved to Gaza and the West Bank. The survivors were swept into a more salinated area, into a reservation, known as ''Siyāj.'' The Bedouin who came from Al-Araqib ("Gentle Hills"), such as the al-Tūris and al-‘Uqbis have nonetheless persisted in returning to their ancestral lands, and their village lies precisely on the 200mm RPA (rainfall per annum) drawn by Israeli meteorologists on the basis of a schema developed by [[Wladimir Köppen]] to define cultivable land from the desert. Two archives have been established to document the local Bedouins rights to their land, one by Nūri al-‘Uqbi and another by Israeli geographer [[Oren Yiftachel]]. Israeli courts have so far rejected suits to reclaim this land, refusing, according to Weizman, to acknowledge Bedouin tenure south of the 200 mm line, which is reserved for kibbutzim and moshavim.<ref>George Prochnik with [[Eyal Weizman]], [https://lareviewofbooks.org/interview/the-desert-threshold 'The Desert Threshold,'] ''[[Los Angeles Review of Books]]'' 18 October 2015.</ref> In 2012 an Israeli court turned down a suit by the al-'Uqbis to have their title, based on a claim of continuous cultivation, recognized by the state.<ref name=AraqimJP>Joanna Paraszczuk and Sharon Udasin, [http://www.jpost.com/NationalNews/Article.aspx?id=262501 'Court rejects 6 Beduin Negev land lawsuits,'] [[Jerusalem Post]] 19 March 2012.</ref>
The [[Jewish National Fund]] planned to include the land of Al-Araqeeb in a new forestation project in the [[Negev Desert]] called ''Ambassadors' Forest'', honoring the assistance provided to Israel by the world's diplomatic corps. This plan spurred objection from some Bedouin living in [[Rahat]] and several villages nearby. In July 2010 the village was demolished by 1,300 police officers, acting under orders of the [[Israel Land Administration]].<ref name="police destroy">{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/police-destroy-dozens-of-buildings-in-unrecognized-bedouin-village-in-negev-1.304443 |title=Police destroy dozens of buildings in unrecognized Bedouin village in Negev |first=Jack |last=Khoury |author2=Yair Yagna |publisher=Haaretz |date=2010-07-28}}</ref>
After a six-year-long court case, in a [[Precedent|precedent-setting]] ruling on March 15, 2012, the Beersheba District court ruled against the six [[lawsuit]]s brought by Al-Uqbi family, which claimed their private [[ownership]] of land in the Al-Araqeeb area.<ref name="JPost">Jerusalem Post, "Court rejects 6 Beduin Negev land lawsuits", March 19, 2012. [http://www.jpost.com/NationalNews/Article.aspx?ID=262501&R=R1]</ref> Based upon the experts' testimony and the presented evidence, the [[judge]] ruled that this land belongs to the [[Sovereign state|State]]. The court ruling was left disregarded - the Bedouin came back to the place 59 times to rebuild the structures, but each time they were razed back by the state.<ref name="Levy Levac" /><ref name="Cook" /> Aziz al-Touri, a representative of the village has asked why Jews are permitted to move to the Negev and live in [[kibbutzim]], [[moshavim]] and isolated farms while that right is denied the Bedouin desiring to dwell in their own villages. The interviewers comment that the 1948 Palestinian exodus never ended.<ref name="Levy Levac" />
==Land ownership== [[File:BeershevaRegion1940s.jpg|thumb|250px|Map of the region surrounding the city of [[Beer Sheba]] in the 1940s depicting the location of al-Araqeeb tribe as 9 kilometers due north of the city]] The Bedouin families of Arakib say they own about 4,600 acres of the [[Negev]] desert,<ref name="LA Times 2010-07-28"/> and that they paid property taxes to the [[Ottoman Empire]] and later to the [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandatory authorities in Palestine]].<ref name="LA Times 2010-07-28">{{cite news |last=Sanders |first=Edmund |title=Israel razes homes in Bedouin village |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/middleeast/la-fg-israel-bedouins-20100728,0,6624860.story |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=July 28, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100801012119/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/middleeast/la-fg-israel-bedouins-20100728%2C0%2C6624860.story |archivedate=1 August 2010 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Community leaders say they were forced by Israel's military into settlements along the border of the [[West Bank]] in 1951, and that they have been pushed off their land whenever they have since tried to return.<ref name="LA Times 2010-07-28"/>
Israeli officials say the property was taken over by the state in the early 1950s because it was abandoned, and because its inhabitants were unable to produce [[deed]]s.<ref name="LA Times 2010-07-28"/> They maintained that the Bedouins have been squatters who refused to pay rent; they [[Tillage|cultivated land]] that did not belong to them, and were [[animal domestication|raising animals]] without [[livestock permit]]s.<ref name="LA Times 2010-07-28"/> Authorities claim that there has never been a permanent Bedouin settlement in the area. The Ottoman authorities permitted the [[clan]] members to graze their sheep and cows on this land, but did not give them ownership over it.
According to the [[Israel Lands Administration]] (ILA), Bedouins began illegally settling in the area in 1998, and several dozen families built homes in the area in 1999 when it appeared the government was attempting to seize the land.<ref name="LA Times 2010-07-28"/> The ILA offered to rent the land for 2 [[New Israeli shekel|NIS]] per [[dunam]], but the inhabitants refused to pay and "continued to infiltrate the land year after year."<ref name="police destroy"/><ref name=jpost /> In 2000, an Israeli court order banned the Bedouins from entering the area. The ruling was disregarded, as Bedouins continued to move into the area and plant trees. In 2003, the ILA secured a court order to evacuate the residents, and the case went to the [[Supreme Court of Israel|Israeli Supreme Court]].<ref name="police destroy"/> In 2004, though one resident speaks of crop dusters poisoning the fields in the later 1990s,<ref name="Levy Levac" /> the [[Israel Land Administration]] used [[crop duster]] [[fumigation]] to destroy the residents' [[wheat]] crops.<ref>{{cite book |page=415 |first=Diana |last=Vinding |title=The Indigenous World 2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P3DjdPS8w1MC&lpg=PA415&dq=Al-Araqeeb&pg=PA415#v=onepage&q=Al-Araqeeb |year=2005 |publisher=[[IWGIA]] |isbn=978-87-91563-05-8}}</ref><ref>Nir Hasson and Haaretz Correspondent, "Negev Bedouin protest home demolitions, crop destruction", ''Haaretz'', Feb 15, 2004. [http://www.haaretz.com/news/negev-bedouin-protest-home-demolitions-crop-destruction-1.114046]</ref> This practice was outlawed by the court in 2007 after the [[Adalah]] legal center for Arab rights in Israel filed a petition to the [[Supreme Court of Israel|Israeli Supreme Court]] on behalf of the residents of Al-Araqeeb and Wadi al-Bakar.<ref>{{cite news |title=State ordered to stop spraying Bedouin land with chemicals|author=Yuval Yoaz|newspaper=Haaretz|date=16 April 2007|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/state-ordered-to-stop-spraying-bedouin-land-with-chemicals-1.218225}}</ref>
Tens of thousands of structures have been built in Bedouin communities, and new ones are built more quickly than the state can demolish them.<ref name="jpost">Ben Hartman, [http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?ID=183689 "State demolishes Beduin homes again"], [[Jerusalem Post]], May 8, 2010</ref> They are illegal since the state never issues construction permits for the [[Unrecognized Bedouin villages in Israel|unrecognized villages]].<ref>{{cite news | author = T. S. Rangwala | title = Inadequate Housing, Israel, and the Bedouin of the Negev | journal = Osgoode Hall Law Journal | volume = 42 | issue = 3 | year = 2004 | pages = 415–472 }}</ref>
In July 2011 the state filed a NIS 1.8 million suit against 34 Bedouins from the Abu Mediam and Abu Jabber families, whom they accuse of illegal encroachment on state lands. The suit seeks to reclaim the state costs of evicting families from the Negev village.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/NationalNews/Article.aspx?id=231200 State sues Beduin of al-Arakib village for NIS 1.8m]</ref>
==Evictions== [[File:Araqeeb Demolished604.JPG|thumb|250px|Demolished house in Al-Araqeeb]] In July 2010, [[Israel Land Administration]] inspectors and 1,300 police officers demolished the villages' 46 buildings and uprooted 850 trees, which were transferred for replanting elsewhere.<ref name="police destroy"/> Witnesses told [[CNN]] that the hundreds of Israeli riot police who stormed the village were accompanied by "busloads of cheering civilians". Israeli police said that there were "no disturbances".<ref name="cnn">{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/07/27/israel.bedouins.demolitions/ |title=Bedouins evicted from village in southern Israel |publisher=CNN |first=Paul |last=Colsey |author2=Kareem Khadder |author3=Ben Wedeman |date=2010-07-27}}</ref> Hundreds of [[olive tree]]s belonging to the villagers were uprooted.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-10777040 |title=Israel police raze 'illegal' Bedouin village in Negev |publisher=BBC |date=2010-07-28}}</ref> Israeli [[Israeli peace camp|left-wing activists]] mildly clashed with police during the demolition.<ref name=Curiel>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3925793,00.html "1,300 policemen guard razing of Bedouin village; Land Administration personnel demolish 45 illegal structures in al-Arakib village, near Rahat."] Ilana Curiel, 07.27.10, Y-nat News.</ref>
Some residents immediately began rebuilding their homes.<ref name="cnn"/> Shlomo Tziser, a Land Administration administrator told the press that, "the people who live here have homes in Rahat and Kfar Kassem. We are implementing a verdict for the evacuation of the area which has passed all legal instances. Today we shall evacuate them and should they return we'll do it again."<ref name=Curiel/>
One week after the last demolition (August 4), the village was razed again after residents returned and rebuilt some parts of it.<ref name=Ynetnews>{{cite news |title=Bedouin village razed again; MK forcefully removed|author=Ilana Curiel|newspaper=Ynetnews|date=8 April 2010|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3930023,00.html}}</ref> Six people were arrested during the second demolition of the village.<ref name=Ynetnews/> The Bedouin [[Knesset]] member, [[Taleb el-Sana]], was forcibly removed from the scene by police after he had tried to stop the demolition.<ref name=Ynetnews/>
Over the next two weeks, the village was demolished a third (August 10) and a fourth time (August 17) after residents rebuilt it.<ref>https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129662776</ref> The demolition on August 17 took place at dawn during [[Ramadan]] while the villagers were fasting. Throughout the following months, residents continued to return to the village and build makeshift structures.
On January 16, 2011, Israeli security forces demolished eleven makeshift buildings. Protesters clashed with police, who responded with pepper spray and paintball guns. Five protesters were injured. Taleb el-Sana attended and told Israeli media that, "The state is pushing its Bedouin citizens to the point where they may launch a popular intifada, which will have severe results."<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4014380,00.html Ilana Curiel, "Bedouin village razed again; residents: Fascist state"], Ynet. Retrieved 2011-01-17</ref> The inhabitants immediately returned to the site. The following day, police arrived at the site and evicted the residents, clashing with them and Israeli leftists. An Israeli police officer was injured by stones thrown at him, and police responded by firing paintballs at protesters, injuring one. Five people were arrested.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4015082,00.html Clash at Bedouin village; 2 injured, 5 arrested], [[Ynetnews]], January 17, 2011]</ref> On January 31, the village was again demolished, while police forces also guarded Jewish National Fund (JNF) forestation work in the area.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4021561,00.html Illegal structures demolished in Bedouin village], [[Ynetnews]], January 31, 2011</ref>
On February 10, 2011, clashes occurred again, after residents and activists disrupted the work of JNF forestry workers.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4026666,00.html Six injured in al-Arakib clashes]</ref> Six people were injured and taken to [[Soroka Medical Center]] in [[Beersheba]], and three villagers were arrested for throwing stones.<ref>Ilana Curiel, [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4026687,00.html Clashes in Bedouin village leave 6 wounded], [[Ynetnews]], February 10, 2011</ref> On February 16, villagers again clashed with JNF workers and their police escorts. Police responded by firing paintballs. Two villagers were lightly injured and taken to Soroka Medical Center.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4029465,00.html "2 lightly injured in al-Arakib clashes"], ''Israel News'', 16 February 2011</ref>
==Court findings== [[File:AlAraqeeb 2007.JPG|thumb|250px|Aerial shot of Al-Araqeeb in 2007 presented by the state in court]] In late 2006, seventeen Bedouin of the al-Uqbi family filed six land claims saying that the land they are on, including Al-Araqeeb, belongs to them. After five years of legal proceedings, the court heard extensive testimonies of experts and witnesses on the behalf of both sides, reviewed historical documents, and scrutinized land laws from the Ottoman period, the British mandate period and that of Israel. The country's leading experts in historical and political geography testified. For the plaintiffs spoke [[Ben-Gurion University of the Negev|Ben Gurion University]]’s Prof. [[Oren Yiftachel]], a [[Critical geography|critical geographer]] and a social scientist. Testifying for the state was Prof. [[Ruth Kark]], a leading expert on the [[historical geography]] of Palestine and Israel from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem|Hebrew University]].<ref name=JPost/>
The plaintiffs argued that the state order to expropriate the land in 1951 was made on the erroneous assumption that under Ottoman law, the land was classified as ''Mawat'' (uncultivated and not adjacent to settled lands). They said that the land had been cultivated and owned by them, and so classified as ''Miri'' land under Ottoman legal terms. In an expert opinion filed to the court, Oren Yiftachel said that these “tribal areas” of scattered tent clusters were not at that time registered with the authorities, but were nevertheless considered settled and met the definition of a “village” in the 1921 Land Ordinance.<ref name=JPost/>
The state’s expert witness, Prof. Ruth Kark, said that prior to 1858 there had been no fixed settlements on or near the disputed land. The first permanent settlement had been Beersheba, which the Ottomans founded in 1900 and which is 11 kilometers from Al-Araqeeb – refuting the Beduin’s claims that the land could not have been Mawat because it was both cultivated and next to a settlement.<ref name=JPost/> The State presented an aerial shot of the place which they said proved that the Al-Araqeeb area had no cultivated land during the British mandate period.<ref name="IToday">Nadav Shragai, "The True Story of Al-Araqeeb", March 19, 2012. ''Israel Hayom (Israel Today)'', Hebrew [http://www.global-report.com/disillusion/a1533-%D7%94%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%A4%D7%95%D7%A8-%D7%94%D7%90%D7%9E%D7%99%D7%AA%D7%99-%D7%A9%D7%9C-%D7%90%D7%9C-%D7%A2%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A7%D7%99%D7%91]</ref> The bedouin presented aerial photographs from 1945 onwards which they said showed extensive cultivation.<ref>{{cite newspaper | title = Court rejects 6 Beduin Negev land lawsuits | newspaper = Jerusalem Post | date = 19 March 2012 | url = http://www.jpost.com/National-News/Court-rejects-6-Beduin-Negev-land-lawsuits}}</ref>
The verdict was presented by Judge Sarah Dovrat in the Beersheba District court on March 15, 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://old.justice.gov.il/MOJHeb/HeskeminVeKishreiHutz/Heskemim/Pirsumim/shonot |title=Civil Case File Nos. 7161/06, 7275/06, 7276/06 1114/07, 1115/07, 5278/08, Suleiman Mahmud Salaam El-Uqbi (deceased) et. al. v. The State of Israel et. al. (15.3.12) |access-date=2012-10-18 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121218213509/http://old.justice.gov.il/MOJHeb/HeskeminVeKishreiHutz/Heskemim/Pirsumim/shonot |archive-date=2012-12-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Based on the experts' testimony and the presented documents, the judge ruled in favor of the State, saying that the land was not "assigned to the plaintiffs, nor held by them under conditions required by law," and that they still had to "prove their rights to the land by proof of its registration in the [[Tapu (Ottoman law)|Tabu]]" (Israel Lands Authority). The judge said that the Bedouin knew they were supposed to register but did not. She said, "The state said that although the complainants are not entitled to compensation, it has been willing to negotiate with them," and that "it is a shame that these negotiations did not reach any agreement." The court also ordered the Bedouin to pay legal costs of 50,000 NIS (approximately U.S. $13,500).<ref name=JPost/>
In its ruling, the court criticized the expert on the behalf of the plaintiffs, stating that his testimony lacked a sufficient factual basis value and reliable basis.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://old.justice.gov.il/NR/rdonlyres/0FA805C1-9BCC-4FB0-8F1E-47CC9E869EC5/37796/ElUqbiEniglishfinal.pdf |title=Full text of court judgement |access-date=2012-10-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202230550/http://old.justice.gov.il/NR/rdonlyres/0FA805C1-9BCC-4FB0-8F1E-47CC9E869EC5/37796/ElUqbiEniglishfinal.pdf |archive-date=2013-12-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In addition, the court held that the Bedouins' own internal documentation indicates they were well aware of the legal requirement to register the lands in the Land Registry, but chose not to do so.<ref name=JPost/> The judge affirmed that the practice of removal of encroached settlements carried out by the State is acceptable and legal.<ref name=JPost/>
In spite of the court ruling, the Al-Araqeeb residents continued to erect structures at the site. On April 23<ref>[http://www.milligazette.com/news/3618-occupation-demolishes-arab-village-for-the-37th-time Occupation demolishes Arab village for the 37th time], The Milli Gazette, Apr 28</ref> and May 23, 2012,<ref>[http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/06/13/220418.html Palestinian villagers demand Guinness entry for demolition record], [[Al Arabiya]], June 13, 2012</ref> Al-Araqeeb was razed again. It was demolished for the 49th time in April 2013.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/04/2013415141817288270.html Bulldozers flatten Bedouin village 49 times], [[Al Jazeera]], April 18, 2013.</ref>
In 2014, "Israeli authorities allegedly issued eviction orders to dead people" in Al-Araqeeb.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/israeli-authorities-try-to-evict-dead-people-from-arab-village-9445736.html Israeli authorities 'try to evict dead people' from Arab village], 28 May 2014, [[The Independent]]</ref>

revision.comment: /* List of species named by Kellner */ fixed wording
revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=December 2009}} {{use British English|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox scientist
| name = Alexander Kellner | image = Alexander_Kellner_at_the_MCTIC.jpg | alt = Middle-aged man with short hair speaking during a meeting. He is wearing a dark blue suit, with a white shirt and wine-colored neck tie. | caption = Kellner in 2018 | image_size = | birth_name = Alexander Wilhelm Armin Kellner | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|9|26}} | birth_place = [[Vaduz]], [[Liechtenstein]] | nationality = Brazilian | fields = [[Paleontology]], [[Geology]]o | work_institution = [[National Museum (Rio de Janeiro)]] | alma_mater = [[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]] | known_for = [[Pterosaurs]], [[dinosaurs]] }}
'''Alexander Wilhelm Armin Kellner''' (born September 26, 1961) is a Brazilian [[geologist]] and [[paleontologist]] who is a leading expert in the field of studying [[pterosaurs]]. His research has focused mainly on [[fossil]] reptiles from the [[Cretaceous]] [[Period (geologic time)|Period]], including extinct [[Dinosaur|dinosaurs]] and [[Crocodylomorpha|crocodylomorphs]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.org.br/resultado.php3?codigo=kellner|title=Membros|last=|first=|date=|website=Academia Brasileira de Ciências|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123143247/http://www.abc.org.br/resultado.php3?codigo=kellner|archive-date=2010-11-23|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Kellner has over 500 publications to his name, has published more than 160 primary studies and two science books. He has participated in paleontological expeditions to many locations including Brazil, Chile, Iran, the United States, Argentina, China, and Antarctica.
His scientific achievements include the description of more than thirty [[species]]. For his work he has received several honors and prizes, including the [[TWAS Prize]] for Earth Sciences from the [[The World Academy of Sciences]] and admission to the [[National Order of Scientific Merit]] (class Comendador), one Brazil's most prestigious awards.
==Biography== Kellner was born in [[Vaduz]], [[Liechtenstein]], son of a German father and Austrian mother.<ref>{{citar web|url=http://www.terra.com.br/istoegente/57/reportagem/rep_cacador.htm|titulo=O caçador de dinossauros|data=|acessodata=2018-11-24|publicado=ISTOÉ Gente Online|ultimo=Cohen|primeiro=Vivianne}}</ref> In his early childhood he moved with his parents to Brazil, where he became naturalised Brazilian.<ref name=":0" />
In [[Rio de Janeiro]] he received a [[Primary education|primary]] and [[secondary education]] at the bilingual [[Deutsche Schule Rio de Janeiro|Escola Alemã Corcovado]].<ref name=":0" /> He began studying [[geology]] at the [[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]] (UFRJ) in 1981. As a student, he soon began researching [[fossil]] [[Vertebrate|vertebrates]], particularly [[Reptile|reptiles]] from Brazil's [[Cretaceous]] [[Geological period|Period]].<ref name=":0" /> His studies focused largely on [[pterosaur]] specimens from the geologic [[Santana Group]], about which he published many papers in the late 1980s.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} He earned a [[Master of Science]] degree in geology at the UFRJ in 1991, a [[M.Phil]] degree in 1994, and a [[Ph.D.]] in 1996 from [[Columbia University]] in New York, in a joint program with the [[American Museum of Natural History]]. In 1997 he became a professor at the Federal University-owned [[National Museum of Rio de Janeiro]] and [[curator]] of its geological and [[paleontological]] departments. From 1998 to 2001, he served as the chairman of these departments and has been head of the [[zoology]] graduate program since 2008.<ref name=":0" /> Kellner is also chief editor of the ''[[Anais da Academia Brasileira de Ciências]]'', the official publication of the [[Brazilian Academy of Sciences]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scielo.br/revistas/aabc/iedboard.htm|title=An. Acad. Bras. Ciênc. - Editorial board|website=www.scielo.br|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref>
[[File:Alexander_Kellner_at_the_Academia_Brasileira_de_Sciencias.png|thumb|left|upright=0.60|Kellner speaking at the [[Brazilian Academy of Sciences]], [[Rio de Janeiro]], in August 2014]]
As part of his work on flying reptiles, Kellner organised the [[Pterosaur Workshop]] at Pittsburgh, USA, in 1995,<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://twas.org/sites/default/files/kellner_cv_2015_twas.pdf|title=Curriculum Vitae (condensed)|last=Kellner|first=A. W. A.|date=2015|website=The World Academy of Sciences|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref> and the first pterosaur [[symposium]] ever held at the American Museum of Natural History in 1996. As well, he was involved in the organisation of several scientific meetings in Rio de Janeiro such as the 31st International Geological Congress in 2000 and the 2nd Latin-American Congress of Vertebrate Paleontology in 2002.<ref name=":0" />
Kellner has organized or taken part in several paleontological expeditions to many locations around the globe, including Brazil—[[Mato Grosso]], [[Rio Grande do Sul]] and [[Ceará]];<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://lattes.cnpq.br/0424535851535945|title=Curriculo do Sistema de Curriculos Lattes (Alexander Wilhelm Armin Kellner)|date=2018|website=National Council for Scientific and Technological Development|access-date=}}</ref> the deserts of [[Atacama]], Chile and [[Kerman]], Iran; [[Montana]] in the United States; [[Patagonia]] in Argentina;<ref name=":0" /> the famous deposits of [[Liaoning]], China,<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/09/12/world/science-health-world/ancient-flying-dragon-reptile-named-avatar-creature/|title=Ancient flying ‘dragon reptile’ named after ‘Avatar’ creature|date=2014-09-12|work=The Japan Times Online|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en-US|issn=0447-5763}}</ref> and [[James Ross Island]] in Antarctica.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2011/08/110824-sea-monster-antarctica-plesiosaur-science-animals/|title=Oldest Antarctic 'Sea Monster' Found|last=Valle|first=Sabrina|date=2011|work=National Geographic|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www1.folha.uol.com.br/internacional/en/scienceandhealth/2016/03/1755522-brazilian-paleontologists-face-43-days-camping-in-freezing-temperatures-and-return-with-three-tons-of-fossils-from-antarctica.shtml|title=Brazilian Paleontologists Face 43 Days Camping in Freezing Temperatures and Return with Three Tons of Fossils from Antarctica|last=Leite|first=Marcelo|date=2016|website=UOL|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref>
Kellner has over 500 publications to his name (including abstracts and science articles). He has published more than 160 primary studies<ref name=":1" /> and two science books: ''Pterossauros - os senhores do céu do Brasil'' ("Pterosaurs — Lords of the Brazilian Sky")<ref>{{Cite book|title=Pterossauros - os senhores do céu do Brasil.|last=Kellner|first=A. W. A.|publisher=Vieira & Lent|year=2006|isbn=858878228-6|location=Rio de Janeiro}}</ref> and the novel ''Na terra dos titãs'' ("In the Land of the Titans").<ref>{{Cite book|title=Na Terra dos Titãs|last=Kellner|first=A. W. A.|publisher=Rocco|year=2007|isbn=9788532521026|location=Rio de Janeiro|pages=}}</ref> He has also taken part in documentaries about fossils (e.g., ''Antarctica - a Summer of 70 million Years'' and ''Dinosaur Hunters'').{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
As a result of his scientific activity he has received several honours, being appointed a member of the Brazilian Academy of Sciences in 1997. He is also an honourable member of the [[New York Paleontologial Society]] and the [[Paleontological Society of Chile]]. He is a research associate of the American Museum of Natural History<ref name=":0" /> and of the Chinese [[Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
Besides his teaching activity, having advised over fifteen master and Ph.D. students, Kellner has been active in the propagation of scientific knowledge to the general public. He organised the 1999 exposition ''No Tempo dos Dinossauros'' ("In the Time of the Dinosaurs") at the [[Museum of Earth Sciences]], which has been regarded as a landmark for the establishment of paleontology in Brazil, attracting the attention of the people of Brazilian to the studies of fossils.<ref name=":0" /> In 2006 he organized the mounting of the first large-scale dinosaur skeleton in Brazil, that of the [[sauropod]] ''[[Maxakalisaurus]] topai'', for which he received recognition from the [[Brazilian Congress]].<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theage.com.au/world/super-maxakalisaurus-from-the-old-cretaceous-20060830-ge311n.html|title=Super maxakalisaurus, from the old Cretaceous|last=Villaverde|first=Julio|date=2006-08-30|website=The Age|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181026104146/https://www.theage.com.au/world/super-maxakalisaurus-from-the-old-cretaceous-20060830-ge311n.html|archive-date=2018-10-26|dead-url=yes|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref> Since 2004 he has written a monthly column in ''Caçadores de Fósseis'' (Fossil Hunters), on the website ''Ciência Hoje On Line'', a project of the [[Brazilian Society for Scientific Progress]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cienciahoje.org.br/coluna_category/cacadores-de-fosseis/|title=Caçadores de Fósseis|work=Ciência Hoje|access-date=2018-10-26|language=pt-BR}}</ref>
Apart from studying their fossils, Kellner has performed important theoretical work on pterosaurs, including [[cladistic]] studies regarding their [[phylogeny]]. In this he is the founder of a distinctive Brazilian school of the study of pterosaurs, with its own favoured phylogenetic model, clade terminology and nomenclature. Rivalling models and nomenclatural choices have been provided by the influential British pterosaur researcher [[David Unwin]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
For his achievements he has received several honours and prizes, including the [[TWAS Prize]] for Earth Sciences from the [[The World Academy of Sciences]].<ref name="Prizes and Awards">{{Cite web |url=http://twas.org/article/twas-announces-2010-prize-winners |title=Prizes and Awards |date=2016 |publisher=The World Academy of Sciences}}</ref> He was admitted in the [[National Order of Scientific Merit]](class Comendador), one the Brazilian Federal Government's most prestigious awards.
==List of species named by Kellner== Kellner's scientific achievements include the description of more than thirty [[species]], of which ''[[Santanaraptor]]'' ''placidus'' (1996, 1999) is among the best examples of soft tissue preservation, including blood vessels and muscle fibers, reported in any [[dinosaur]]. The pterosaur ''[[Thalassodromeus]] sethi'', which Kellner described in 2002 with his colleague Diogenes de Almeida Campos, allowed for the establishment of a new hypothesis regarding the use of the head crest in body temperature regulation of pterosaurs.<ref name=":0" />
A complete list of new species described and named by Kellner, sometimes in cooperation with other researchers, includes:
[[File:20130825_Brazil_Rio_de_Janeiro_0144.jpg|thumb|Reconstructed skeleton of the [[spinosaurid]] dinosaur ''[[Angaturama]]'', [[National Museum of Rio de Janeiro]]]]
*''[[Brasileodactylus]] araripensis'' Kellner, 1984 ([[Reptilia]], [[Pterosauria]]) * ''[[Anhanguera (pterosaur)|Anhanguera]] blittersdorffi'' Campos & Kellner, 1985 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Oshunia]] brevis'' Wenz & Kellner, 1986 ([[fish|Pisces]], [[Halecomorphi]]). * ''[[Caririsuchus]] camposi'' Kellner, 1987 (Reptilia, [[Crocodylia]]) * ''[[Tupuxuara]] longicristatus'' Kellner & Campos, 1988 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Tapejara (pterosaur)|Tapejara]] wellnhoferi'' Kellner, 1989 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''Tupuxuara leonardii'' Kellner & Campos, 1994 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Angaturama]] limai'' Kellner & Campos, 1996 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Ongghonia]] dashzevegi'' Kellner & McKenna, 1996 ([[Mammalia]], [[Leptictidae]]) * ''[[Tupandactylus]] imperator'' (Campos & Kellner, 1997) (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Siroccopteryx]] moroccensis'' Mader & Kellner, 1999 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Gondwanatitan]] faustoi'' Kellner & Azevedo, 1999 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Santanaraptor]] placidus'' Kellner, 1999 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''Anhanguera piscator'' Kellner & Tomida, 2000 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Stratiotosuchus]] maxhechti'' Campos, Suarez, Riff & Kellner, 2001 (Reptilia, Crocodylia) * ''[[Thalassodromeus]] sethi'' Kellner & Campos, 2002 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) [[File:Thalassodromeus in Japan.jpg|thumb|Reconstructed skeleton of the pterosaur ''[[Thalassodromeus]]'' at the [[National Museum of Nature and Science]], [[Tokyo]]]] * ''[[Pycnonemosaurus]] nevesi'' Kellner & Campos, 2002 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Kaikaifilusaurus]] calvoi'' Simón & Kellner, 2003. (Reptilia, [[Sphenodontia]]) * ''[[Unaysaurus]] tolentinoi'' Leal, L.A., Azevedo, S.A., Kellner, A.W.A. & Rosa, Á.A.S., 2004 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Unenlagia]] paynemili'' Calvo, J.O., Porfiri, J. & Kellner, A.W.A., 2004 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Feilongus]] youngi'' Wang, Kellner, Zhou & Campos, 2005 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Nurhachius]] ignaciobritoi'' Wang, Kellner, Zhou & Campos, 2005 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Baurutitan]] britoi'' Kellner, A.W.A., Campos, D. A., Trotta, M. N. F. 2005 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Trigonosaurus]] pricei'' Campos, D.A., Kellner, A.W.A., Bertini, R.J., Santucci, R.M. 2005 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Caririemys]] violetae'' Oliveira, G.R. & Kellner, A.W.A. 2007 (Reptilia, Testudines) * ''[[Gegepterus]] changi'' Wang, Kellner, Zhou & Campos, 2007 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Futalognkosaurus]] dukei'' Calvo, J.O., Porfiri, J., González-Riga, B.J. & Kellner, A.W.A., 2007 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Nemicolopterus]] crypticus'' Wang, Kellner, Zhou & Campos, 2008 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Guarinisuchus]] munizi'' Barbosa, Kellner & Viana, 2008 (Reptilia, Crocodylia) * ''[[Hongshanopterus]] lacustris'' Wang, Zhou, Campos & Kellner, 2008 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Coringasuchus]] anisodontis'' Kellner, A.W.A., Pinheiro, A.E.P., Azevedo, S.A.K., Henriques, D.D.R., Carvalho, L.B. & Oliveira, G. 2009 (Reptilia, Crocodylia) * ''[[Wukongopterus]] lii'' Wang, Kellner, Jiang, Meng 2009 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Dawndraco]] kanzai'', Kellner 2010 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Geosternbergia]] maysei'', Kellner 2010 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) *''[[Oxalaia]]'' ''quilombensis'', Kellner, A.W.A., Machado E.B., Azevedo, S.A.K., Henriques D.R., Carvalho, L.B., 2011 (Reptilia, Dinosauria) * ''[[Europejara]] olcadesorum'', Vullo, Marugán-Lobón, Kellner, et al. 2012 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Caupedactylus]] ybaka'', Kellner 2013 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Caiuajara]] dobruskii'', Manzig, Kellner, et al. 2014 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Austriadraco]]'', Kellner 2015 (Reptilia, Pterosauria) * ''[[Bergamodactylus]]'', Kellner 2015 (Reptilia, Pterosauria)

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2008}} {{globalize|date=December 2010}} A bill of sale is a document that transfers ownership of goods from one person to another. It is used in situations where the former owner transfers possession of the goods to a new owner. Bills of sale may be used in a wide variety of transactions: people can sell their goods, exchange them, give them as gifts or mortgage them to get a loan. They can only be used: * to transfer ownership of goods that people already own; * to transfer ownership of moveable tangible goods; and * by individuals and unincorporated businesses. Bills of sale exist at [[common law]] quite independently of any legislation. In England and Wales, they are regulated by two Victorian pieces of legislation: the Bills of Sale Act 1878 and the Bills of Sale Act (1878) Amendment Act 1882. This area of the law was subject to review by the [[Law Commission (England and Wales)|Law Commission]], which published a proposal for change in 2017.{{cite report |url=https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/662596/PRINT_-_From_Bills_of_Sale_to_Goods_Mortgages.pdf |title=From Bills of Sale to Goods Mortgages |isbn=978-1-5286-0110-8 |publisher=House of Commons |work=Law Commission |id=HC 495/Law Com No 376 |date=23 November 2017 |accessdate=20 August 2018}} == Bills of sale in the US == ===Historical origin=== The term “bill of sale” originally referred to any writing by which an absolute disposition of personalty for value was effected or evidenced. A common feature of such dispositions is that the owner mortgagor remains in possession and exercises all the attendant rights of ownership, which may be so overwhelming as to induce a third party to accept the same chattel as a security for a grant, albeit without notice of the first mortgagee. This scenario made the bill of sale a veritable tool of fraud. The evolution of various bills of sale laws, within the USA, was to curb the use of the bill of sale as a means of defrauding innocent persons. The first of such being the [[Bills of Sale Act 1854]] which was repealed and re-enacted by the [[Bills of Sale Act 1878]] which was almost on all fours with the 1854 act. Further developments led to the enactment of the [[Bills of Sale Act 1882]]. A bill of sale has been defined as a legal document made by the seller to a purchaser, reporting that on a specific date at a specific locality and for a particular sum of money or other value received, the seller sold to the purchaser a specific item of personal property, or parcel of real property of which he had lawful possession . The Black’s Law Dictionary on its part defines a bill of sale as “an instrument for the conveyance of title to personal property, absolutely or by way of security”. According to Omotola the bill of sale is “a form of legal mortgage of chattels”. Bullen and Leake and Jacobs define a bill of sale as “a document transferring a proprietary interest in personal chattels from one individual (the “grantor”) to another (the “grantee”), without possession being delivered to the grantee”. In essence, a bill of sale is a written instrument showing the voluntary transfer of a right or interest or title to personal property, either by way of security or absolutely, from one person to another without the actual physical possession of the property leaving the owner and being delivered to the other party. It is clear from the definitions above that the bills of sale are essentially of two types: The absolute bill of sale and the conditional bill of sale.{{cite web |url=http://www.documatica-forms.com/usa/bill-of-sale/more-info.php |title=What is a USA Bill of Sale or Documented Sales Receipt? |deadurl=no |accessdate=4 August 2013}} ===The absolute bill of sale=== Absolute bills of sale, which do not represent any form of security whatsoever, are simply documents evidencing assignments, transfers and other assurances of personal chattels, which are substantially no more than mere [[contract of sale|contracts of sale]] of goods covered by the common law of contract and the sale of goods law. ===The conditional bill of sale=== The conditional bill of sale refers to any assignment or transfer of personal chattels to a person by way of security for the payment of money. The conditional bill of sale creates a security in favour of the grantee of the bill whereby the grantee is given personal right of seizure giving right to a security interest of a possessory nature. There are other forms of security over goods such as a pledge and contractual lien which also only give right to a security interest of a possessory nature. An example of a conditional bill of sale can be found where a creditor gives a loan and has transferred to himself, as collateral or security for the loan, the title of the goods or other personal property of the debtor. The physical goods or other property however remains with the debtor. == Bills of sale in England and Wales == === Historical perspective === Bills of sale have existed at common law since at least the [[Middle Ages]], when they were most commonly used commercially in the shipping industry. As the general population began to own more personal goods in the [[Victorian era]], bills of sale came to be used as a form of consumer credit. Lenders would extend credit on the security of:
''all and every the household goods, furniture, plate, linen, china, books, stock in trade, brewing utensils and all the effects.''J Weir, "The Law of Bills of Sale" (1896) p.23
Most often, people would grant bills of sale over their goods as security for a loan. Borrowers would transfer ownership of their goods to the lender, while retaining possession of them when making repayments. When the loan was repaid, the borrower would regain ownership. Bills of sale used in this way are known as “security bills”. Sometimes, bills of sale would transfer ownership outright, such as when a person sold their goods to another while retaining possession. Bills of sale used for purposes other than borrowing money are known as “absolute bills”. === Bills of Sale Acts === The increased use of bills of sale in the Victorian era created a “false wealth” problem. Potential purchasers and other lenders could be misled into thinking that the person in possession of goods still owned them. The person in possession could sell the goods or use them to secure another loan. In both cases, the transaction was fraudulent, but the purchaser or lender had no way of discovering that the goods were already subject to a bill of sale. As a result, Parliament passed the Bills of Sale Act 1878. This largely replicated the provisions of an earlier Bills of Sale Act 1854. It requires all bills of sale to be registered at the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] so that interested third parties could check whether the person in possession has already transferred away ownership of goods. The Bills of Sale Act (1878) Amendment Act 1882 had a different purpose. The 1878 Act led to a rise in the use of security bills. Concerns were expressed that such transactions could lead “thousands of honest and respectable people to their ruin”.Hansard (HC), 20 March 1882, vol 267, cc1398-416. Parliament noted that:
''Many money-lenders advertised under the names of fictitious banks; and sometimes they advertised in this form – “A widow, with capital to spare, will be happy to lend on easy terms. Strict secrecy. Five per cent.”… Having entrapped a man into his office, the money-lender proceeded in this way – He produced a bill of sale containing a large number of clauses, which it was impossible for the borrower to read or understand in the time allowed...''
In response, Parliament enacted the 1882 Act, which was an early attempt at consumer protection. Both the 1878 Act and the 1882 Act remain in force today. Absolute bills are regulated only by the 1878 Act. Security bills are regulated by the 1882 Act and the 1878 Act, to the extent that its provisions are consistent with those of the 1882 Act. === Bills of sale in the 21st century === In the twenty-first century, bills of sale are overwhelmingly used in the form of so-called “[[Logbook loan|logbook loans]]”.{{cite report |url=http://www.lawcom.gov.uk/app/uploads/2015/09/cp225_bills_of_sale.pdf |title=Bills of Sale - A Consultation Paper |id=Consultation Paper No 225 |publisher=Law Commission |year=2015 |isbn=9780108561702 |accessdate=20 August 2018}}{{rp|12}} These are security bills secured on the borrower’s vehicle. Borrowers transfer ownership of their car, van or motorcycle to the logbook lender as security for the loan. While making repayments, borrowers keep possession of their vehicle and continue to use it. Borrowers hand the logbook lender the V5C registration document – or “logbook” – but this is purely symbolic and has no legal effect. === Criticism and reform of the law === The law of bills of sale has been criticised on a number of occasions. The Crowther report in 1971Report of the committee on consumer credit (1971) Cmnd 4596. and the Diamond report in 1986A Diamond, ''A review of security interests in property'' (1989) both considered the Acts, with the latter recommending repeal. In its consultation paper, the Law Commission made a number of criticisms of the law as it stood in 2015. It proposed to replace the Bills of Sale Acts with a new Goods Mortgages Act.{{rp|71}} In its consultation paper, the Law Commission identified five key problems with the Bills of Sale Acts: * undue complexity; * highly technical documentation; * the registration regime is in need of modernisation; * they offer little protection to borrowers; * they offer no protection to third party purchasers.{{rp|7}} The Law Commission proposed to replace the Bills of Sale Acts with a new Goods Mortgage Act that would address each of the criticisms identified in the consultation paper. ==See also== * [[Contract of sale]] * [[Hire purchase]] * [[Manufacturer’s Certificate of Origin]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/41-42/31/contents Bills of Sale Act 1878] *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/45-46/43/contents Bills of Sale Act (1878) Amendment Act 1882] *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/53-54/53/contents Bills of Sale Act 1890] *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/54-55/35/contents Bills of Sale Act 1891] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bill Of Sale}} [[Category:Sales]] [[Category:Legal documents]] [[Category:Accounting source documents]]

[[File:Jefferson Memorial At Dusk 1.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Jefferson Memorial]] designed by [[John Russell Pope]] was featured on the cover of one of the first books in the ''Buildings'' series]] {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Buildings of the United States''}} '''''Buildings of the United States''''' is a multi-volume series of illustrated reference works.<ref name=Buildings>{{cite web|title=Buildings of the United States|url=http://www.sah.org/publications-and-research/buildings-of-the-us|publisher=Society of Architectural Historians|accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref> The series focuses on the architectural history and legacy of various States, regions, or metropolitan areas, "identifying the rich cultural, economic, and geographical diversity of the United States as it is reflected in the architecture. . . " <ref>{{cite web|title=Buildings of the United States|url=http://uiuc.libguides.com/content.php?pid=317714&sid=2646525|work=Library Guide: Basic Architectural Sources|publisher=University of Illinois|accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> The books in the series are intended as a resource for academics, architects, and preservationists, as well as guidebooks for the general public. Each volume is intended to be written by an individual expert or contributing experts. The series is sponsored by the [[Society of Architectural Historians]], having established its editorial board, consisting of academics and representatives of the [[National Park Service]], the [[Library of Congress]], and the [[American Institute of Architects]]. As of 2012, the head of the editorial committee is Professor Emerita at [[Tulane University]], Karen Kingsley, Editor-in-Chief and Managing Editor. The Society also coordinates fundraising for the project.
The series is a planned 60-volume work. Work on the series was inspired by [[Nikolaus Pevsner]]'s ''[[Pevsner Architectural Guides|Buildings of England]]'' guidebooks. The Society has overseen the publication of 25 volumes since 1993.<ref name=Published>{{cite web|title=Published Volumes|url=https://www.sah.org/publications-and-research/buildings-of-the-us/published-and-forthcoming-volumes|publisher=Society of Architectural Historians|accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref> The series first 10 volumes were published by [[Oxford University Press]] and since 2006, it has been published by the [[University of Virginia Press]].<ref name=Buildings></ref> Its first four volumes (1993) on buildings in Alaska, the District of Columbia, Iowa, and Michigan (2nd ed. 2012) received American publishing awards, and its volumes on Colorado (1997) and Louisiana (2004) have also received honors. The most recent volume is New Orleans (2018). In addition to the foregoing, the existing series includes volumes on architecture in Arkansas (2018); Delaware (2008), Georgia: Savannah (2016), Hawaii (2011), Massachusetts: Metropolitan Boston (2009), Nevada (2000), North Dakota (2015), Philadelphia and Eastern Pennsylvania (2010), Pittsburgh and Western Pennsylvania (2007 and 2010), Rhode Island (2004), Texas: Central, South and Gulf Coast (2013), Virginia: Tidewater and Piedmont (2002), and Valley, Piedmont, Southside, and Southwest (2014), Vermont (2014), Wisconsin (2017), and West Virginia (2004).
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:American architecture]] [[Category:Specialized encyclopedias]]
==External links== *[http://sah-archipedia.org SAH Archpedia] - an online reference website from the same publisher that uses some content from the book series.
