page.title: Persecution of Christians in the modern era

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
{{about|persecution of Christians since 1989|persecution of Christians in previous centuries|Persecution of Christians}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Status of religious freedom |Persecution}} {{Modern persecutions of the Catholic Church}}
The [[Pew Research Center]] has performed studies on international [[religious freedom]], researching restrictions on religion originating from government prohibitions on [[free speech]] and religious expression as well as social hostilities undertaken by private individuals, organisations and social groups.<ref name="prc-1">{{cite web |title=Global Restrictions on Religion (Executive summary)|publisher=The Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life|date=December 2009|url=http://pewforum.org/docs/?DocID=491|accessdate=29 December 2009}}</ref><ref name="prc-2">{{cite web|title=Global Restrictions on Religion (Full report)|publisher=The Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life|date=December 2009|url=http://www.pewforum.org/files/2009/12/restrictions-fullreport.pdf|accessdate=12 September 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223318/http://www.pewforum.org/files/2009/12/restrictions-fullreport.pdf|archive-date=3 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In many countries around the world, Christians are subject to restrictions on speech, and suffer [[communal violence]] and [[hate crime]]s.
Scientific research about anti-Christian prejudice is not as well-developed as research about [[Antisemitism|anti-Semitism]] and [[Islamophobia]]. This is because the scientific study of prejudice, first undertaken by the pioneering Harvard psychologist [[Gordon Allport]] began in Christian cultural contexts where atheists and religious minorities such as Jews were the obvious out-groups<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Allport|first=Gordon W.|date=1966|title=The Religious Context of Prejudice|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1384172|journal=Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion|volume=5|issue=3|pages=447–457|doi=10.2307/1384172}}</ref>. More recently, sociologists have began to explore anti-Christian prejudice. For example, in a small-scale exploratory study of adolescent Christians in England, participants reported concern that being Christian was associated with lower peer-group status and intellectual inferiority (in comparision to atheists). Adolescent Christians also reported the use of slurs by school peers, such as 'bible-basher', and other hostile offensive jokes and comments<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moulin|first=Daniel|date=2016|title=Reported Experiences of Anti-Christian Prejudice among Christian Adolescents in England|url=https://www.academia.edu/25082790/Reported_experiences_of_anti-Christian_prejudice_among_Christian_adolescents_in_England|journal=Journal of Contemporary Religion|language=en|volume=31|issue=2|pages=223–238|doi=10.1080/13537903.2016.1152679|issn=1353-7903|via=}}</ref>.
== Anti-Christian expressions == [[File:Peter's Cross.svg|thumb|right|The Cross of St. Peter or Petrine Cross is an inverted Latin cross traditionally used as a Christian symbol, but in recent times also used as an anti-Christian symbol.]]
===Arson=== {{main|Church arson}} Arson attacks on churches have been seen in Norway and the United States. Some arson attacks are considered [[hate crime]]s perpetrated for racial reasons by people inspired by racial [[hate group]]s.<ref name="time.com-arson">{{cite news|last=Fulton |first=Greg |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1171196,00.html |title=Time Magazine |publisher=Time.com |date=2006-03-08 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref><ref name="washpost-motivations">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/longterm/churches/churches.htm |title=Washington Post article |publisher=Washington Post article |date= |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> Headliners of the [[black metal]] genre have claimed responsibility for inspiring (and sometimes perpetrating) over fifty [[Norway|Norwegian]] church burnings from 1992 to 1996 alone.<ref name=grude>{{cite video | people = Grude, Torstein (Director) |date=1 January 1998|url=http://home.no/metalra/reviews/videos/satan_rides_the_media.html |title=Satan rir Media | medium = motion picture |location=Norway |publisher=Grude, Torstein}}</ref> Among the most notable was [[Fantoft Stave Church]], which the police believed was destroyed by the one-man band [[Burzum]], [[Varg Vikernes]], also known as 'Count Grishnackh'.<ref name=grude /> The burnt-out shell of the building is featured on the cover of his 1993 [[extended play|EP]] ''[[Aske (EP)|Aske]]'' (Norwegian for 'ashes').
===Vandalism=== The [[vandalism]] or [[defacement (vandalism)|defacement]] of Christian property is one form of the expression of anti-Christian sentiment. The destruction of property held by churches and Christian individuals can be in violation of various criminal laws, and can violate [[hate speech]] laws if it is racially or religiously motivated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/peoria/2015/01/07/vandals-scrawl-hate-speech-across-phoenix-church/21422467/|title=Vandals scrawl hate speech across Phoenix church|date=7 January 2015|work=azcentral}}</ref>
== Examples of anti-Christian sentiment in politics and culture ==
===Middle East=== {{see also|Christianity in the Middle East}} Fiorello Provera of the [[European Parliament]] called the Middle East "the most dangerous place for Christians to live" and cited [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], who blamed the international community for failing to deal with what she considers a war against Christians in the Muslim world.<ref>{{cite news|last=Provera |first=Fiorello |title=Fiorello Provera: Christianity's Via Dolorosa |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Project_Syndicate/Story/STIStory_786856.html |accessdate=7 June 2012 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |date=9 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607042116/http://www.straitstimes.com/Project_Syndicate/Story/STIStory_786856.html |archivedate=7 June 2012 }}</ref>
Former Lebanese president [[Amine Gemayel]] stated in 2011 that Christians had become the target of [[genocide]] after dozens of Christians were killed in deadly attacks in Egypt and Iraq.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-Lebanon Leader: Christians Target of Genocide|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/2100-202_162-7208414.html|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=3 January 2011}}</ref>
According to Israeli ambassador to the United States [[Michael Oren]], in the hundred years leading up to 2010 the Middle East's Christian population dwindled from 20% to less than 5%. Oren argues that with the exception of Israel, Christians in the Middle East have endured severe political and cultural hardships: in Egypt, Muslim extremists have subjected Coptic Christians to beatings and massacres, resulting in the exodus of 200,000 Copts from their homes; in Iraq, 1,000 Christians were killed in Baghdad between the years 2003 and 2012 and 70 churches in the country were burned; in Iran, converts to Christianity face the death penalty and in 2012 Pastor [[Yousef Nadarkhani]] was sentenced to death; in Saudi Arabia, private Christian prayer is against the law; in the Gaza Strip, half of the Palestinian Christian population has fled since Hamas seized power in 2007 and Gazan law forbids public displays of crucifixes; in the West Bank, the Christian population has been reduced from 15% to less than 2%.<ref>{{cite news|last=Oren|first=Michael|title=Israel and the Plight of Mideast Christians|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203960804577239923033348982|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=9 March 2012|authorlink=Michael Oren}}</ref>
====Egypt==== {{see also|Maspero demonstrations}} In Egypt, the government does not recognize religious conversions from Islam to Christianity.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fowler|first=Lilly|title=Coptic Christian ex-patriots keep a wary eye on Egyptian elections|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/on-faith/coptic-christian-ex-patriots-keep-a-wary-eye-on-egyptian-elections/2012/06/18/gJQAL9d1lV_story.html|accessdate=23 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=18 June 2012}}</ref> Foreign missionaries are allowed in the country if they restrict their activities to social improvements and refrain from [[proselytizing]]. The [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic]] [[Pope Shenouda III]] was internally exiled in 1981 by President [[Anwar Sadat]], who then chose five Coptic bishops and asked them to choose a new pope. They refused, and in 1985 President [[Hosni Mubarak]] restored Pope Shenouda III, who had been accused of fomenting interconfessional strife. Particularly in Upper Egypt, the rise in extremist [[Islamist]] groups such as the [[Gama'at Islamiya]] during the 1980s was accompanied by increased attacks on Copts and on Coptic Orthodox churches; these have since declined with the decline of those organizations, but still continue. The police have been accused of siding with the attackers in some of these cases.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/589977.stm |title=Funerals for victims of Egypt clashes |publisher=BBC News |date=4 January 2000 |accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref>
In April 2006, one person was killed and twelve injured in simultaneous knife attacks on three Coptic Orthodox churches in Alexandria.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4909378.stm |title=Knife attacks on Egypt churches |publisher=BBC News |date=14 April 2006 |accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref>
Since the overthrow of Hosni Mubarak in 2011, Egypt's Coptic Christians have been the target of increasing opposition and discrimination.{{fact|date=February 2018}} In 2011, anti-Christian activity in Egypt included church burnings, protests against the appointment of a Coptic Christian governor in [[Qena Governorate|Qena]], and deadly confrontations with the Egyptian army. On television Islamists referred to Christians as heretics and said they should be made to pay the [[jizya]] tax. A Coptic priest accused Islamists in the country of massacring uninfected pigs predominantly owned by Copts during a [[swine flu]] scare: "They killed these innocent pigs just because they thought they violated their religion in some way." In October 2011 a draft resolution passed by the [[European Parliament]] accused Egypt of persecuting the country's Christian population. By mid-2012 10,000 Christians had fled the country.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fathi|first=Yasmine|title=Egypt Copts react to Islamist electoral win|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/28346.aspx|accessdate=19 June 2012|newspaper=[[Ahram Online]]|date=4 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="mostafa">{{cite news|last=Mostafa|first=Abdallah|title=EU parliament accuses Egypt of persecuting Christian minority|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/eu-parliament-accuses-egypt-persecuting-christian-minority|accessdate=19 June 2012|newspaper=[[Al-masry Al-youm|Egypt Independent]]|date=28 October 2011}}</ref><ref name=tevrov />
In July 2012, [[Dahshur]]'s entire Christian community, which some estimate to be as many as a hundred families, fled to nearby towns due to sectarian violence. The violence began in a dispute over a badly ironed shirt, which in turn escalated into a fight in which a Christian burned a Muslim to death, which in turn sparked a rampage by angry Muslims, while the police failed to act. At least 16 homes and properties of Christians were pillaged, some were torched, and a church was damaged during the violence.<ref name="Riot leaves christians">{{cite news | url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/riot-leaves-egyptian-village-christians-16930420 | title=Riot leaves an Egyptian village without Christians | publisher=ABC News | agency=Associated Press | date=4 August 2012 | accessdate=5 August 2012 | author=El Deeb, Sarah}}</ref>
From 2011 to 2013, more than 150 kidnappings, for ransom, of Christians had been reported in the [[Minya governorate]].<ref>{{Cite news | first=Hamza | last=Hendawi | title=Christians being targeted by kidnappers in Egypt | url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/04/04/3323290/kidnappers-target-christians-in.html| work= | newspaper=[[Florida Today]] | location=[[Melbourne, Florida]] | pages= 11A | date=7 April 2013 | id= | accessdate=}}</ref> <!---hard copy source differs from soft copy but is the same Associated Press item--->
There is a long-running tension between Christians and Muslims in areas like Minya over whether churches may appear in the village. It is possible, legally speaking, for Christians to get a permit for built churches. However, civilian mobs are liable to attack the building if one's house is thought of as an unlicenced or not-yet-licensed church, or if one is thought to be building a new church. Some Muslim villagers see churches as unclean. <ref>{{cite web |last1=Arraf |first1=Jane |title=For Christians In Egypt, Building A New Church Can Set Off Violence |url=https://www.npr.org/2017/06/14/532891324/for-christians-in-egypt-building-a-new-church-can-set-off-violence |website=National Public Radio |publisher=NPR |accessdate=3 July 2018 |date=14 June 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, Egyptian poet Fatima Naoot was convicted of "contempt of religion" and sentenced to three years in jail for a 2014 Facebook post criticising animal killing during Eid.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mourad |first=Mahmoud |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-courts-poet-idUSKBN0L121M20150128 |title=Egyptian poet goes on trial accused of contempt of Islam |publisher=Reuters |date=2015-01-28 |accessdate=2016-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/185963/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-writer-Fatima-Naoot-sentenced-to--years-i.aspx |title=Egyptian writer Fatima Naoot sentenced to 3 years in jail for ‘contempt of religion’ - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2016-04-02}}</ref> Four Coptic Christian juveniles were convicted of "contempt of religion" the next month, with three of them sentenced to five years in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/egyptian-coptic-teens-hit-jail-sentence-contempt-islam-132419988.html |title=Egypt sentences Christian teens to jail for contempt of Islam |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date=2016-02-25 |accessdate=2016-04-02}}</ref>
====Iraq and Syria==== {{See also|Christianity in Syria|Persecution of Christians by ISIL|Sectarianism and minorities in the Syrian Civil War#Christians}}
The consolidation of power in the hands of Shiite Islamists in Iraq since the overthrow of the Saddam Hussein regime has been to the detriment of Iraq's [[Assyrian people|Assyrian]] and [[Armenians|Armenian]] Christian communities. Friction between rival sects in [[Iraq]] has frequently resulted in violence being directed against Christians in the country. Consequently, there has been a flight of Christians from some areas to Europe and to the United States. Since 2003, hundreds of thousands of Christians have fled Iraq, such that the Christian population, which may have been as high as 1.4 million prior to the Iraq War, has dropped to 500,000, with numbers continuing to decline. Between 2003 and 2012 more than 70 churches were bombed. In 2007 Al Qaeda militants killed a young priest in Mosul, and in 2010 gunmen massacred 53 [[Assyrian Christians]] in a Baghdad church.<ref name=tevrov>{{cite news|last=Tevrov|first=Daniel|title=Syrian Christian Support For Assad Regime May Turn Out To Be A Losing Strategy|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/352983/20120616/syria-chirstians-bashar-al-assad-opposition.htm|accessdate=18 June 2012|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=16 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Pope marks Easter with call for end to violence in Syria|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/04/08/pope-marks-easter-with-call-for-end-to-violence-in-syria/|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[Fox News]]|date=8 April 2012|agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Christians fleeing Iraq|url=http://www.watertowndailytimes.com/article/20120314/OPINION01/703149971/1036|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[Watertown Daily Times]]|date=14 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Arraf|first=Jane|title=A northern Iraqi Easter|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2012/0408/A-northern-Iraqi-Easter|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=8 April 2012}}</ref>
During the [[Syrian Civil War]] and the spillover into Iraq, [[persecution of Christians by ISIL]] and other militant groups has been ongoing. The [[Fall of Mosul]] and the Assyrian town of [[Qaraqosh]] in the [[Northern Iraq offensive (June 2014)|2014 ISIL advance]] in Iraq led to an estimated 100,000 Assyrian Christian civilians being displaced. After the fall of Mosul, ISIL demanded Assyrian Christians in the city to [[Forced conversion|convert to Islam]], pay tribute, or face execution.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28381455|title=BBC News - Iraqi Christians flee after Isis issue Mosul ultimatum|work=BBC News|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref> ISIL begun marking homes of Christian residents with the [[Nun (letter)|letter ''nūn'']] for ''Nassarah'' ("Christian").<ref name="BBC-1">{{cite news |date=August 7, 2014 |title=Iraqi Christians flee after Isis issue Mosul ultimatum |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28381455 |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140724045752/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28381455 |archivedate=24 July 2014 |accessdate=August 7, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Telegraph-2">{{cite news |last=Loveluck |first=Louisa |date=August 7, 2014 |title=Christians flee Iraq's Mosul after Islamists tell them: convert, pay or die |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/10977698/Christians-flee-Iraqs-Mosul-after-Islamists-tell-them-convert-pay-or-die.html |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140730003543/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/10977698/Christians-flee-Iraqs-Mosul-after-Islamists-tell-them-convert-pay-or-die.html |archivedate=30 July 2014 |accessdate=August 7, 2014 }}</ref> Thousands of Christians, Yazidis (the latter whom were given only the choice of conversion or death) and other, mostly [[Shi'a]] Muslims (whom ISIL consider to be [[Apostasy in Islam|apostates]]) have abandoned their homes and land. The [[destruction of cultural heritage by ISIL]] has included the [[The Mosque of the Prophet Yunus (Jonah)|Mosque of the Prophet Jonah]], revered in all Abrahamic faiths.
====Israel==== [[File:Vandalized graveyard.jpg|thumb|right|A vandalized Christian graveyard in [[Bethlehem]]. The text says "Death to Arabs" in Hebrew.]]
In Jerusalem, there have been instances of Christian churches and monasteries being vandalized with spray-painted offensive remarks against Christianity, including death threats. These are believed to be [[Price tag policy|price tag]] attacks by extremist settlers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Zaimov|first=Stoyan|title=Christianity in Jerusalem Under Attack? Extremists Hit Another Church|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/christianity-in-jerusalem-under-attack-extremists-hit-another-church-69974/|accessdate=10 June 2012|newspaper=The Christian Post|date=21 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Elgot|first=Jessica|title=Rabbis condemn attacks on Israel's Christian sites|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/israel-news/64295/rabbis-condemn-attacks-israels-christian-sites|publisher=The Jewish Chronicle|accessdate=10 June 2012}}</ref>
In Tel Aviv in 2008, three teenagers burned hundreds of Christian Bibles.<ref>In a 2008 Tel Aviv incident, hundreds of copies of the New Testament, which had been handed out in the city (allegedly by [[Messianic Jews]] in order to convert Ethiopian Jews), were burned by three teenaged Orthodox students of Judaism. Uzi Aharon, the town's deputy mayor, told CNN he had collected the New Testaments but that he did not plan for them to be burned. The youths had done so while he was not present. Once he found out that the fire was going, he put it out.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Bixler |first=Mark |title=Hundreds of New Testaments torched in Israel |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2008-05-28/world/bible.burning_1_messianic-jews-deputy-mayor-israeli-radio-and-television?_s=PM:WORLD |accessdate=23 June 2012 |newspaper=CNN |date=28 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121055311/http://articles.cnn.com/2008-05-28/world/bible.burning_1_messianic-jews-deputy-mayor-israeli-radio-and-television?_s=PM%3AWORLD |archivedate=21 January 2012 |df= }}</ref>
A number of Ultra-Orthodox/[[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] youth have reportedly spat at Christian clergymen. Archbishop Aris Shirvanian, of Jerusalem's Armenian Patriarchate, says he personally has been spat at about 50 times in the past 12 years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArt.jhtml?itemNo=487412&contrassID=2&subContrassID=5&sbSubContrassID=0&listSrc=Y&itemNo=487412 |title=Christians in Jerusalem want Jews to stop spitting on them |publisher=[[Haaretz]] |first=Amiram |last=Barkat |date=27 June 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Rosenberg|first=Oz|title=Ultra-Orthodox spitting attacks on Old City clergymen becoming daily|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/ultra-orthodox-spitting-attacks-on-old-city-clergymen-becoming-daily-1.393669|accessdate=10 June 2012|newspaper=Haaretz|date=4 November 2011}}</ref> The [[Anti-Defamation League]] has called on the chief Rabbis to speak out against the interfaith assaults.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adl.org/PresRele/IslME_62/4576_62.htm |title=ADL Calls On Chief Rabbis to Speak Out Against Interfaith Assaults In Old City |date=17 October 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081129013512/http://www.adl.org/PresRele/IslME_62/4576_62.htm |archivedate=29 November 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Father Goosan, Chief [[Dragoman]] of the [[Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem]], stated that, "I know there are fanatical Haredi groups that don't represent the general public but it's still enraging. It all begins with education. It's the responsibility of these men's yeshiva heads to teach them not to behave this way".<ref>{{cite news |title=Ultra-Orthodox spitting attacks on Old City clergymen becoming daily |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/ultra-orthodox-spitting-attacks-on-old-city-clergymen-becoming-daily-1.393669 |author=Oz Rosenberg |newspaper=Haaretz |date=15 November 2011}}</ref> In January 2010, Christian leaders, Israeli Foreign ministry staff, representatives of the Jerusalem municipality and the Haredi community met to discuss inter-faith tolerance. The Haredi Community Tribunal of Justice published a statement condemning harassment of Christians, stating that it was a "desecration of God's name." Several events were planned in 2010 by the [[Modern Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] Yedidya congregation to show solidarity with Christians and improve relations between the Haredi and Christian communities of Jerusalem.<ref name="HaaretzSpitting">{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1154366.html |title=Capital Anglos mobilize against practice of spitting at Christians |publisher=[[Haaretz]] |date=5 March 2010 |first=Rachel |last=Ahren}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ahren|first=Raphael|title=Capital Anglos mobilize against practice of spitting at Christians|url=http://www.haaretz.com/capital-anglos-mobilize-against-practice-of-spitting-at-christians-1.264213|publisher=Haaretz|accessdate=23 June 2012}}</ref>
In July 2012, a former member of the [[Knesset]], [[Michael Ben-Ari]], who supports [[Kahanism]], videotaped himself tearing up a copy of the [[New Testament]] and throwing it in the trash. Ben-Ari referred to it as a "despicable book" that should be "in the dustbin of history".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au//news/breaking-news/mp-tears-up-copy-of-new-testament/story-fn3dxix6-1226428642613|title=MP tears up copy of New Testament | work=The Australian | date=18 July 2012}}</ref> In response, the [[American Jewish Committee]] urged the Knesset to [[censure]] Ben-Ari, while a spokesman for [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] also condemned Ben-Ari's actions.<ref name="benari">{{cite web|url=http://www.sacbee.com/2012/07/18/4639333/ajc-urges-knesset-to-censure-mk.html |title=AJC Urges Knesset to Censure MK Ben-Ari for New Testament Desecration |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723102649/http://www.sacbee.com/2012/07/18/4639333/ajc-urges-knesset-to-censure-mk.html |archivedate=23 July 2012 }}</ref>
====Palestine==== {{further|Islamization of the Gaza Strip|The Teacher's Bookshop}} [[Palestinian Media Watch]] (PMW) reported that state-controlled Palestinian media frequently demonize religions like Judaism and Christianity. PMW translated into English a children's television program aired twice in 2012 it said featured a young girl saying Jews and Christians are "cowardly and despised."<ref>{{cite news|last=Zaimov|first=Stoyan|title=Palestinian TV Criticized for Using Young Girl to 'Promote Hate' Toward Christians, Jews|url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/palestinian-tv-criticized-for-using-young-girl-to-promote-hate-toward-christians-jews-76962/|accessdate=23 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Christian Post]]|date=20 June 2012}}</ref>
=====West Bank===== In 2002, a mob of Palestinian Muslims burned Christian property in Ramallah.<ref>{{cite news|last=Radin|first=Charles A.|title=Defendants killed in court; mob fears grow in West Bank|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-7705112.html|accessdate=23 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=6 February 2002}}</ref> A dossier submitted in 2005 to Church leaders in Jerusalem listed 93 incidents of abuse alleged to have been committed against Palestinian Christians by Muslim extremists and 140 cases of gangs allegedly stealing Christian land in the West Bank.<ref>{{cite news|last=de Quetteville|first=Harry|title='Islamic mafia' accused of persecuting Holy Land Christians|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/palestinianauthority/1498033/Islamic-mafia-accused-of-persecuting-Holy-Land-Christians.html|accessdate=23 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=9 September 2005|location=London}}</ref> In May 2012 a group of 100 Muslims attacked Taybeh, a Christian village in the West Bank.<ref>{{cite news|title=Muslim attacks against Christians on the rise in West Bank |url=http://www.worldnewstribune.com/2012/05/28/muslim-attacks-against-christians-on-the-rise-in-west-bank/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160212000435/http://www.worldnewstribune.com/2012/05/28/muslim-attacks-against-christians-on-the-rise-in-west-bank/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 February 2016 |accessdate=23 June 2012 |newspaper=World Tribune |date=28 May 2012 }}</ref>
=====Gaza===== In 2007, the Gaza Strip had a tiny Christian minority of 2,500–3,000. The Hamas overthrow of the Palestinian Authority in Gaza during that year was accompanied by violent attacks against Christians and Christian holy sites by Islamic militants. A Catholic convent and Rosary Sisters school were ransacked, with some Christians blaming Hamas for the attack. In September 2007 Christian anxiety grew after an 80-year-old Christian woman was attacked in her Gaza home by a masked man who robbed her and called her an [[kafir|infidel]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Hadid|first=Diaa|title=For Gaza's Christians, new reality unsettling|url=http://www.chron.com/news/nation-world/article/For-Gaza-s-Christians-new-reality-unsettling-1807109.php|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Houston Chronicle]]|date=27 June 2007|agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Abu Toameh|first=Khaled|title=Christian-Muslim tensions heat up|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast//Article.aspx?id=76420|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=25 April 2007|authorlink=Khaled Abu Toameh}}</ref> That attack was followed less than a month later by a deadly assault on the owner of the only Christian bookstore in Gaza City. Muslim extremists were implicated as being behind the incident.<ref>{{cite news|last=Silver|first=Eric|title=Gaza's Christian bookseller killed|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/gazas-christian-bookseller-killed-396283.html|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=8 October 2007|location=London}}</ref> The library of the [[Young Men's Christian Association]] (YMCA) was bombed in 2008 by gunmen who, according to guards at the site, asked why the guards worked for "infidels."<ref>{{cite news|title=Militants bomb Gaza YMCA library|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7246454.stm|accessdate=17 June 2012|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=15 February 2008}}</ref>
In 2011, the Christian population of Gaza Strip was less than 1,400. A member of the Catholic faith told ''[[The Guardian]]'' he was stopped by a Hamas official and told to remove a wooden crucifix he was wearing.<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenwood|first=Phoebe|title=Gaza Christians long for days before Hamas cancelled Christmas|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/23/gaza-christians-hamas-cancelled-christmas|accessdate=17 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=23 December 2011|location=London}}</ref>
====Saudi Arabia==== The human rights advocacy group International Christian Concern (ICC) told the ''[[Christian Post]]'' that 35 Christian Ethiopians – men and women – were violently arrested in [[Jeddah]] in December 2011 while holding a prayer meeting in their home. The prisoners complained of being persecuted on account of their faith and of being pressured to convert to Islam, and the women reported undergoing a humiliating strip search. According to the ICC, one prisoner said, "The Muslim preacher [that was sent by officials to speak to the prisoners] vilified Christianity, denigrated the Bible and told us that Islam is the only true religion."<ref>{{cite news|last=Oleszczuk|first=Luiza|title=Christians Imprisoned in Saudi Arabia Pressured to Convert to Islam|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/christians-imprisoned-in-saudi-arabia-pressured-to-convert-to-islam-69067/|accessdate=23 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Christian Post]]|date=9 February 2012}}</ref>
===Europe===
====Norway==== [[File:Anti-Christian graffiti.jpg|thumb|Anti-Christian [[graffiti]] in [[Tampere]], [[Finland]]]] On 6 June 1992, the [[Fantoft Stave Church]], a wooden structure originally built in 1150 in Fortun and moved to Bergen in 1883, was burnt down.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pv8EfgI8VwMC&pg=RA1-PA185&lpg=RA1-PA185&dq=Fantoft+stave+church+burned+down&source=bl&ots=eetMou6hJU&sig=p1s4gtlFfuKwV4dzmU1RYYKUm6s&hl=en&ei=G55GSvbDH5WxjAfcpelk&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4 |title=In Cod We Trust, By Eric Dregni. p.185 |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2008-09-22 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> At first the fire was attributed to lightning and electrical failure. In January 1993 [[Varg Vikernes]], also known as "Count Grishnackh", was interviewed by a local journalist in his apartment decorated with 'Nazi paraphernalia, weapons and Satanic symbols'. Vikernes, at the time a proponent of [[White nationalism]], [[social conservatism]], [[survivalism]] and his [[Neo-völkisch movements|Neo-völkisch]] ideology, declared that he wanted to blow up [[Blitz (movement)|Blitz House]] and [[Nidaros Cathedral]]. He has publicly supported black metal fans burning down eight churches in Norway. He used a photo of the charred remnants of one church taken soon after the fire on his band [[Burzum]]'s EP entitled ''[[Aske (EP)|Aske]]'' ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] for ashes). Following his statement, the Norwegian authorities began to clamp down on black metal musicians.<ref name = VIKERNES>{{cite news|author=Chris Campion |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2005/feb/20/popandrock4 |title=In the face of death |publisher=Guardian |date= 21 February 2005|accessdate=12 February 2013 |location=London}}</ref>
In 1994, Vikernes was found guilty of murder, arson and possession of illegal weapons (including explosives) and given the maximum sentence under Norwegian law of 21 years in prison.<ref name = VIKERNES/> He was released in 2009.<ref>{{Cite news| title= Ute av fengsel | url= http://www.dagbladet.no/2009/05/22/nyheter/black_metal/varg_vikernes/6354526/ | work= Dagbladet.no | date= 22 May 2009 | accessdate=23 May 2009 | language= Norwegian| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090525083544/http://www.dagbladet.no/2009/05/22/nyheter/black_metal/varg_vikernes/6354526/| archivedate= 25 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The following is a partial list of Norwegian Christian church arsons in 1992 by anti-Christian groups reported by English-language media sources: *23 May: Storetveit Church in [[Bergen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/hh-lords.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309061629/http://thetruemayhem.com/interviews/previous/hh-lords.htm|title=New Page 1|archivedate=9 March 2009|work=thetruemayhem.com}}</ref> *6 June: [[Fantoft Stave Church]] in [[Bergen]].<ref name=LoC78>Lords of Chaos (1998): 78</ref> Varg Vikernes was suspected of the crime, but denied this;<ref name = VIKERNES/> he was not convicted.<ref name=LoC78 /> *1 August: Revheim Church in [[Stavanger]].<ref name=LoC78 /> *21 August: [[Holmenkollen]] Chapel in [[Oslo]].<ref name=LoC79>Lords of Chaos (1998): 79</ref> *1 September: Ormøya Church in Oslo.<ref name=LoC79 /> *13 September: [[Skjold, Rogaland|Skjold]] Church in [[Vindafjord]].<ref name=LoC79/> Varg Vikernes and Samoth were convicted for this. *October: Hauketo Church in Oslo.<ref name=LoC79 /> *24 December: [[Åsane]] Church in [[Bergen]].<ref name=SrM>[[Satan rir media|Satan rides the Media]] (1998)</ref> Varg Vikernes and musician [[Jørn Inge Tunsberg]] were convicted for this.<ref name=autogenerated1>Satan rides the Media</ref> *25 December: a Methodist church in [[Sarpsborg]].<ref name=SrM /> A firefighter was killed while fighting this fire.<ref name=SrM />
==== Russia ==== Many attacks, arsons and acts of vandalism against churches in Russia are reported each year.<ref>[http://en.ria.ru/art_living/20121018/176713485.html Pope Supports Russian Church’s Position on Vandalism] MOSCOW, October 18 (RIA Novosti)</ref><ref name="ria.ru">[http://ria.ru/religion/20081201/156224544.html Acts of vandalism against Orthodox churches in Russia, 1998-2008] RIA Novosti, 14:46 01.12.2008</ref> The acts of vandalism are often accompanied by [[Satanism|Satanic]] symbolism and graffiti.<ref>[http://tbn-tv.ru/vera/po-rossii-katitsya-volna-vandalizma-v-gorodax-oskvernyayutsya-cerkvi-i-xramy ПО РОССИИ КАТИТСЯ ВОЛНА ВАНДАЛИЗМА: В ГОРОДАХ ОСКВЕРНЯЮТСЯ ЦЕРКВИ И ХРАМЫ] http://tbn-tv.ru/</ref> In many instances, icons and crosses are burned and vandalized, and swastikas and Satanic symbols are painted on the walls of the churches (while in other attacks on churches in Russia they can be understood as more simple robberies).<ref name="ria.ru"/> Some of the attacks on the churches, such as the cutting down of crosses, appear to be conducted by groups organized online and by local youth.<ref>[http://russian.rt.com/inotv/2012-08-28/Antireligioznie-vandali-nashlis-v-Internete Антирелигиозные вандалы нашлись в Интернете] 28 августа 2012, Russia Today</ref>
====Sweden==== On 7 February 1993, the [[Lundby New Church]] in [[Gothenburg]], [[Sweden]] was burnt down.
====United Kingdom==== In the [[United Kingdom Census 2011|2011 UK Census]], 59.5% of the population marked their religion as "Christian", making Christianity still the majority religion.<ref>http://www.ons.gov.uk/census/2011-census/index.html</ref> [[Rowan Williams]] said in 2013 that Christians in the UK who feel "mildly uncomfortable" at "not being taken very seriously" or "being made fun of" in the UK should not compare themselves to minority groups facing "murderous hostility" in countries that lack freedom of religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/10244716/Persecuted-British-Christians-need-to-grow-up-says-former-Archbishop-Rowan-Williams.html|title='Persecuted' British Christians need to 'grow up', says former Archbishop Rowan Williams|publisher=|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref>
[[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] politician [[Mark Pritchard (politician)|Mark Pritchard]] has said that a "[[politically correct]] brigade" were causing, "Christianophobia". Keith Porteous Wood, of the [[National Secular Society]], replied "Christians have absolutely nothing to complain about in this country", he cited the facts that 26 bishops sit in the House of Lords, that England has an established church, and added: "The head of state is a Christian, the prime minister is a Christian and almost all the cabinet are self-identified Christians. How on earth can anyone imagine that Christians are disadvantaged or pushed to the margins?" <ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7125521.stm Christianophobia warning from MP] BBC News 4 December 2007</ref>
In 2007, a church building in Brighton was vandalised with anti-Christian graffiti by squatters.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/sussex/6708959.stm Anger as squatters wreck church] BBC News, 31 May 2007</ref>
===Africa===
====Mali====
The Islamist group [[Ansar Dine]] has led to Christians fleeing their cities to avoid being put under sharia law.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57409633/christians-flee-from-islamists-in-northern-mali/ Christians flee from Islamists in northern Mali] retrieved 17 August 2012</ref>
====Sudan====
The Foreign Missionary Society Act of 1962 put a limit on the number of churches constructed. Students in military training were forbidden from praying unlike Muslims.<ref>Human rights and religion – Page 257 Liam Gearon – 2002</ref>
====Zanzibar====
In Muslim-majority [[Zanzibar]], part of [[Tanzania]] there have been numerous attacks on churches. A bishop condemned the lack of action by the government.<ref>[http://www.persecution.org/2012/06/01/tanzanian-church-leaders-demand-action-after-islamic-radicals-attack-churches-in-zanzibar/ Tanzanian church leaders demand action] retrieved 17 August 2012</ref>
===Americas===
====Bolivia==== An angry mob of Indigenous peoples destroyed the only Protestant church in the remote village of Chucarasi in the Bolivian Andes after beating a congregational elder unconscious. Villagers apparently attacked their Christian neighbors because they blamed them for a hail storm that damaged local crops.<ref>[http://www.worldwatchmonitor.org/english/country/bolivia/2004/newsarticle_0145.html/]{{dead link|date=October 2013}}</ref>
====Chile==== The killing of the priest Faustino Gazziero in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivo.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2004/julio/28-julio-2004/nacional/nacional-20040728-12.html |title=Estupor en Chile por sacerdote asesinado, El Nuevo Diario, Nicaragua |publisher=Archivo.elnuevodiario.com.ni |date= |accessdate=12 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216135458/http://archivo.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2004/julio/28-julio-2004/nacional/nacional-20040728-12.html |archivedate=16 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> CNTV program The Comedy Club parodies of Jesus,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.observatoriofucatel.cl/sigue-la-disputa-por-parodia-del-club-de-la-comedia/ |title=Sigue la disputa por parodia del Club de la Comedia, Observatorio de Medios FUCATEL, 11/10/10 |publisher=Observatoriofucatel.cl |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> the burning of the image of Our Lady of Mount Carmel (national Patroness),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/chilean_bishops_deplore_attack_against_our_lady_of_carmel_at_cathedral_of_santiago/|title=Chilean bishops deplore attack against Our Lady of Carmel at Cathedral of Santiago|work=Catholic News Agency}}</ref> and the subsequent mock of the faithful's grief in a nationwide newspaper.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.muevetechile.org/index.php?view=article&catid=43&id=144:the-clinic-ofende-a-la-virgen-del-carmen&tmpl=component&print=1&page= |title=No permitas que The Clinic ofenda a la Virgen del Carmen, Muévete Chile, 12/05/08 |publisher=Muevetechile.org |date=2012-12-03 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
Since 2015, twelve churches have been burned in southern Chile, 10 Catholic ones and two Protestant ones. Attacks are supposedly from the Mapuche indigenous people, who are campaigning to reclaim ancestral lands, according to authorities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/04/12/indigenous-militants-burn-another-church-in-southern-chile/|title=Indigenous militants burn another church in southern Chile|date=12 April 2016|publisher=|accessdate=28 November 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005003941/http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/04/12/indigenous-militants-burn-another-church-in-southern-chile/|archivedate=5 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
"We are going to burn all churches." Thus declared the note left at the ruins of the Christian Union Evangelical church in Ercilla, Chile, after an arson attack on March 31, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://irishcatholic.ie/article/chile%E2%80%99s-burning-discontent|title=Chile's burning discontent - The Irish Catholic|publisher=|accessdate=28 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161004224600/http://irishcatholic.ie/article/chile%E2%80%99s-burning-discontent|archive-date=4 October 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Cuba==== Government regulations aimed at curbing the growth of Christian house churches in Cuba<ref>[http://www.worldwatchmonitor.org/english/country/cuba/2005/newsarticle_3998.html/]{{dead link|date=October 2013}}</ref>
====United States==== Jay Scott Ballinger admitted to committing 30 to 50 [[church arson]] attacks in 11 states between 1994 and 1998. Ballinger, who describes himself as a [[Satanist]], spray-painted an [[inverted cross]] on the steps of one church they burned, saying it was part of a Satanic ritual.<ref name="ballinger">{{cite web|url=http://www.culteducation.com/reference/satanism/satanism36.html|title=Suspect with Satanic impulses confesses to burning churches}}</ref><ref name="ball2">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1171196,00.html|title=Unusual Suspects in Church Burnings | work=Time | date=8 March 2006}}</ref>
===Asia===
====China==== [[Christians in China]] have been detained, denied the protection of the laws<ref>[https://www.gospelherald.com/articles/71874/20181024/chinese-christians-living-nightmare-under-xi-jinping-new-report.htm]</ref>, and ordered to refrain from religious activities outside of China's single official Protestant church.
====India==== [[File:Girl sufferedwithburnwounds.jpg|thumb|right|A Christian girl who was bruised and burnt by Hindu nationalists during [[anti-Christian violence in India|anti-Christian violence]] in Orissa in August 2008.]]
{{main|Anti-Christian sentiments in India}}
====North Korea==== {{main|Human rights in North Korea}}
====Pakistan==== [[Christianity in Pakistan|Christians in Pakistan]] are a minority, making up 1.6% of the population, and [[Religious discrimination in Pakistan|religious minorities]] are frequently discriminated against.<ref name="LoC">{{cite web |url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Pakistan.pdf |title=Country Profile: Pakistan |date=February 2005 |work=[[Library of Congress Country Studies]] on Pakistan |quote=''Religion: Approximately 1.6 percent of the population is Hindu, 1.6 percent is Christian, and 0.3 percent belongs to other religions, such as Bahaism and Sikhism.'' |publisher=[[Library of Congress]] |accessdate=2013-02-19}}</ref> The [[Blasphemy law in Pakistan|Pakistan blasphemy law]] mandates that blasphemy of the [[Qur'an]] is to be punished. Critics of the laws say that Christians like [[Asia Bibi blasphemy case|Asia Bibi]] are sentenced to death with only hearsay for evidence of alleged blasphemy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/asia/last-ditch-appeal-to-save-asia-bibi-sentenced-to-death-under-pakistans-tough-blasphemy-laws/story-fnh81fz8-1227111607653|title=Last ditch appeal to save Asia Bibi, sentenced to death under Pakistan's tough blasphemy laws|date=4 Nov 2014|author=Debra Killalea|work=News.com.au}}</ref> At least a dozen Christians have been given death sentences,<ref>{{cite news|title=Q&A: Pakistan's controversial blasphemy laws|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12621225|accessdate=15 November 2012|newspaper=BBC}}</ref> and half a dozen of them have been murdered after being accused of violating blasphemy laws. In 2005, 80 Christians were behind bars due to these laws.<ref>{{cite web|title=Christians often victims under Pakistan's blasphemy law|url=http://www.evangelizationstation.com/htm_html/Around%20the%20World/Pakistan/christians_often_victims_under_p.htm|accessdate=15 November 2012}}</ref>
Christians in Pakistan have been murdered in outbreaks of [[communal violence]], such as the [[2009 Gojra riots]], and they have been targeted by militant groups, with the [[Peshawar church attack]] killing 75 Christians in [[Peshawar]] in 2013,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/23/world/asia/pakistan-church-bombing.html?_r=0 New York Times: "Suicide Attack at Christian Church in Pakistan Kills Dozens" by ISMAIL KHAN and SALMAN MASOOD] September 22, 2013</ref> and the [[Lahore church bombings]] killing 15 Christians in 2015.<ref name="geo.tv">{{cite web|url=http://www.geo.tv/article-178233-Two-blasts-at-Lahore-churches-claim-15-lives-|title=Two blasts at Lahore churches claim 15 lives - PAKISTAN - geo.tv|date=15 March 2015|work=geo.tv}}</ref><ref name="agencies-imrangabol-nadeemhaider-waseemriaz-abbashaider-akbarali1">{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1169713|title=15 killed in Taliban attack on Lahore churches|author=Agencies - Imran Gabol - Nadeem Haider - Waseem Riaz - Abbas Haider - Akbar Ali|work=dawn.com}}</ref> The campaign of violence by the [[Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan]] has been described as a [[genocide]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/guest-article-after-the-malala-yousafzai-shooting-can-shock-therapy-free-pakistan/300253-56.html |title=After the Malala Yousafzai shooting, can shock therapy free Pakistan? |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/problem-pakistan-814969 |title=The Problem Of Pakistan |publisher=Ibtimes.com |date= |accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/pakistan-should-be-on-the-genocide-watch-list-us-think-tank/1/222213.html |title=Pakistan should be on the genocide watch list: US think tank |publisher=Indiatoday.intoday.in |date=2012-09-26 |accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Christianity|Human Rights|Discrimination}} {{columns |colwidth=20em |col1 = *[[Anti-clericalism]] *[[Anti-Catholicism]] *[[Anti-Protestantism]] *[[Anti-Eastern Orthodox sentiment]] *[[Anti-Mormonism]] *[[Christmas controversy]] *[[Discrimination against atheists]] * [[George Weigel]] * [[Joseph H. H. Weiler]] *[[Rejection of Jesus]] |col2 = '''Related topics''' *[[Anti-Judaism]] *[[Antisemitism]] *[[Antireligion]] *[[Antitheism]] *[[Civil and political rights]] * [[Christianity and other religions]] * [[Islamophobia]] * [[Persecution of Christians]] * [[Anti-Shi'ism]] }}
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == *[[Michael Moynihan (journalist)|Michael Moynihan]], Didrik Søderlind. ''Lords of Chaos: The Bloody Rise of the Satanic Metal Underground'', {{ISBN|0-922915-48-2}}.
== External links == {{Commons category|Anti-Christianity}} * [http://www.intoleranceagainstchristians.eu/ Observatory on Intolerance and Discrimination against Christians in Europe] * [http://www.uscirf.gov/ US Commission on International Religious Freedom] * [http://www.naacd.com/ National Alliance Against Christian Discrimination] * [http://www.christianophobia.eu/ Website about Christianophobia] * [http://msnbc.msn.com/id/10653030/ News article on Bjorn Atldax Anti-Christian logo jeans] * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2004/12/07/wphob07.xml&sSheet=/news/2004/12/07/ixworld.html News article about Christianophobia] * [http://www.spiegel.de/international/zeitgeist/0,1518,492955,00.html News article about the Vatican's reaction to a "Seven Wonders of the World" contest that 'excluded' Christian monuments] * [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1058/is_33_115/ai_53390006 Protecting persecuted Christians] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090312234211/http://www.zenit.org/article-25317?l=english Anti-Christian: a "Socially Acceptable Prejudice"] * {{cite web|url=http://www.licc.org.uk/engaging-with-culture/connecting-with-culture/religion/the-excommunication-of-rocco-buttiglione--173 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614223351/http://www.licc.org.uk/engaging-with-culture/connecting-with-culture/religion/the-excommunication-of-rocco-buttiglione--173 |archive-date=2011-06-14 |dead-url=yes |title=The London Institute for Contemporary Christianity - Engaging with Culture - Connecting with Culture - The Excommunication of Rocco Buttiglione|accessdate=14 September 2014}} * [http://www.opendoorsusa.org/ Open Doors USA]

page.title: Public Register of All Arms and Bearings in Scotland

revision.comment: added [[Category:Heritage registers in Scotland]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''Public Register of All Arms and Bearings in Scotland''', established in 1672, is an official register of [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[coat of arms|coats of arms]] maintained by the [[Lyon Clerk and Keeper of the Records]]. As a public register, it can be seen by anyone on application, and on payment of a statutory fee.
==History== The Register was established by [[Act of Parliament|Act]] of the [[Scottish Parliament]] in 1672. It is held at the [[Court of the Lord Lyon]], and contains every [[grant of arms]] by [[Lord Lyon King of Arms]] since that date, as well as older coats of arms that the owners have chosen to register. Bearings that are not matriculated in the Register may not be used in Scotland, unless it can be proved that they were in use before 1672.
The first volume of the Register (now divided into two parts for ease of handling and conservation reasons) continued in use from 1672 until 1804, and contains 2,702 entries.<ref>Paul 1903, p. xvi.</ref> It begins with the arms of the Lyon Office, followed by the personal achievement of Sir [[Charles Erskine (officer of arms)|Charles Erskine]], [[Baronet|Bt]], who was Lord Lyon at the time. Most of the arms in this volume are given in [[blazon]] only: relatively few are painted.<ref>Paul 1903, pp. xiv–xvi.</ref>
From the beginning of the second volume in 1804 the arms are consistently painted.<ref>Paul 1903, p. xvii.</ref> The Register now consists of over eighty volumes of [[parchment]], and is illustrated by a succession of the most prominent heraldic artists working in [[Scotland]].
==Published ordinaries== In 1893, Sir [[James Balfour Paul]], [[Lord Lyon King of Arms]], published the contents of the first twelve volumes of the Register, to that date, in the form of an [[Ordinary of arms|ordinary]] (i.e. with the entries in blazon, rearranged by design; and with a name index): the work contained roughly 5,200 entries. Ten years later, by which time the Register had reached its sixteenth volume, he published an updated second edition including all arms registered to the end of 1901: this edition contained 5,532 entries. By 1973 the Register had reached its 57th volume, and in 1977 [[Court of the Lord Lyon|Lyon Office]] published a second volume of the ''Ordinary'': this covered all arms registered from 1902 to the end of 1973, and contained a further 6,040 entries. This volume was edited by David Reid of Robertland, [[Carrick Pursuivant]] (who died in December 1973, while the work was in progress), and Vivien Wilson.
The three published volumes are therefore: * {{cite book |first=Sir James Balfour |last=Paul |authorlink=James Balfour Paul |title=An Ordinary of Arms contained in the Public Register of all Arms and Bearings in Scotland |place=Edinburgh |publisher=William Green & Sons |year=1893 }} * {{cite book |first=Sir James Balfour |last=Paul |authorlink=James Balfour Paul |title=An Ordinary of Arms contained in the Public Register of all Arms and Bearings in Scotland |edition=2nd |place=Edinburgh |publisher=William Green & Sons |year=1903 }} * {{cite book |editor1-first=David |editor1-last=Reid |editor2-first=Vivien |editor2-last=Wilson |title=An Ordinary of Arms contained in the Public Register of all Arms and Bearings in Scotland, 1902–1973 |volume=2 |place=Edinburgh |publisher=H.M.S.O. |year=1977 |isbn=0-9505299-0-7 }}
==Digitisation== The Register down to 1913 has been digitised, and is available on the [[National Archives of Scotland#ScotlandsPeople Website|ScotlandsPeople Website]] (maintained by the [[National Archives of Scotland]]). Searching the index is free, but there is a fee to view the page images.
==See also== *[[Heraldry]] *[[Court of the Lord Lyon|The Court of the Lord Lyon]] *[[Lyon Clerk and Keeper of the Records]] *[[Heraldry Society of Scotland|The Heraldry Society of Scotland]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |first=Sir James Balfour |last=Paul |authorlink=James Balfour Paul |chapter=Introduction |title=An Ordinary of Arms contained in the Public Register of all Arms and Bearings in Scotland |edition=2nd |place=Edinburgh |publisher=William Green & Sons |year=1903 |pages=ix–xxiv }}
==External links== * [http://www.lyon-court.com/ The Court of the Lord Lyon] * [http://www.heraldry-scotland.co.uk The Heraldry Society of Scotland] * [http://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk/Content/Help/index.aspx?r=554&1283 The Public Register of All Arms and Bearings in Scotland on the ScotlandsPeople Website]
